column2: Smithianism

Laissez-faire philosophies, such as minimizing the role of government intervention and taxation in the free markets, and the idea that an "invisible hand" guides supply and demand are among the key ideas Adam Smith's writing is responsible for promoting. Our trade policies are largely inspired by him.
Orthodox Liberal School

The Orthodox school of economic thought, also known as the French Liberal School or Oprtimist School, voraciously defends free trade and laissez-faire capitalism. They are the primary opponents of collectivist, interventionist and protectionist ideas.  Our trade policies are largely inspired by this school.
No Set Trade Policy
Our government doesn't have a set trade policy and prefers to make snap decisions on tariffs.
Mercantilism

Mercantilism is a type of policy designed to maximize the trade of a nation and especially to maximize the accumulation of gold and silver. It promotes governmental regulation of a nation's economy for the purpose of augmenting state power at the expense of rival national powers.
Economic Nationalism

The aim of this policy is to have a country that is economically independent and nationally self-sufficient. It favors policies that emphasize domestic control of the economy, labor, and capital formation, even if this requires the heavy imposition of tariffs and other restrictions on the movement of labor, goods and capital.
Raising Regional Armies

We've called upon regional lords to contribute their vast resources and manpower in exchange for greater autonomy and rights in the future. While this allows us access to a far larger army, giving over such privileges means we will lose most control over certain regions, which in turn could have major consequences in the future.
Low Carrying Capacity

A combination of poor land distribution policy and traditional agricultural/mining practices limits our ability to exploit the land in this region. Reform and new technologies will allow us to use this land to its full potential.
Korean Occupation
The native Han of the region chaff under Korean rule, many choosing to leave to join their brethren to the south.
The Korean Advance
The Hwaryeong's Ever Victorious Armies have advanced into the region, causing a mass exodus of the native Han seeking to avoid the horrors of war.
Highlander Raids
Highlander raiders are looting our provinces in numbers.
Baby Boom
Improvements in life conditions in our country are leading to a country-wide baby boom.
Mandate of Heaven in Question

The plethora of disasters, natural and manmade, and our inability to properly address them is putting our right to rule in question. Local governors are blatently embezzling tax revenue, bandits wander freely across the countryside, and the realm teeters on the brink.
Mandate of Heaven Accepted
Our right to rule has been accepted by the populace. Things could be better but, then again, they could be worse.
Mandate of Heaven Unquestionable
The growing prosperity of the realm breeds further prosperity as China finally stabilises. Take care, however, for chaos too compounds upon itself.
The Count of Shu

Defending the ever-shrinking frontier with the northern barbarians has bred in Shu a generation of men for whom luxury is as foreign as submission. With new lessons from north and west, we, the count of Shu, shall ride forth to defend the realm from all threats, whether from the outside or from within.
The Duke of Zhou

The Yellow River was once the birthplace of the Han of China, our cradle and stronghold. Now, the would-be Han of Korea have defiled the river and their great, fertile floodplain with their presence. We, the Duke of Zhou, are the last defenders of the true Han and we will reclaim our homeland, or perish in the attempt.
The Prince of Wu

Guardians of the great Yangtze and custodians of the imperial capital, the men of Wu have ensured the prosperity of the Ming dynasty for generations through shrewd business practices and skillful political maneuvering. Just as we manage the lifebringing Yangtze and all its great wealth, the prince of Wu will keep the Ming dynasty afloat in these troubled times.
The Prince of Yue

The Pearl River flows into the great Southern Sea, which opens up to the world beyond the Middle Kingdom, to the spice-rich lands of India, the coal burning west, and beyond. It is from the Pearl River the foreigners first arrived in their great black ships and from the Pearl River Yue derives its strength. We, the prince of Yue, bring with us the winds of change, whatever they themselves may bring.
The Marquis of Min

Every three years an uprising, every five years a rebellion. Always far from the mainland's concerns, we of Min have had to fend for ourselves against the hostile barbarian natives and the merciless sea. Piracy, civil conflict, and foreign invasions without help from Nanjing have bled our island nigh dry at times. Yet we have endured, stronger and hardier than all the rest of China. We know our domain, we know how to rule both men and waves. That is the legacy of the marquis of Min.
The Viscount of Xi

If any city can truly be called the heart of the Ming Empire, it would be Changsha, the seat of the viscounts of Xi, the center of the Middle Kingdom. We of Xi bring with us the beating pulse of the Ming dynasty, for all silver must flow through us at some point. As the old saying goes, 'All messages run through our horses, all men pass through our gates, for all roads lead to Changsha.'
